151443205.review:
[h1]This game definitely belongs in this world![/h1]
It's very easy to pick up and play due to its very simple controls. You can only move; all attacks are automatic so you don't need to learn a bunch of button combinations to understand how they work. Yet there's a lot of depth behind the simplicity, which mainly comes down to which combination of weapons you use and how you build your character as you go. Each weapon has a different form of attack but you may not necessarily get to select the ones you want as the selections you get on level up are random so you can't just repeat the exact same build over and over.

You also get that adrenaline rush every time you play - there are satisfying visual effects every time you level up and open a chest that are very similar to what you'll find in casinos and paid loot boxes in other games. The main difference is that opening chests in this game is free and a reward for slaying more powerful monsters, not by paying-to-win. It's designed to be addictive, but without being predatory.

After every run, you can use the gold you earn to purchase unlocked characters as well as powerups which are permanent and apply to all characters. This allows the game to have some form of progression structure despite having to rebuild your character from scratch every single time. Even if you're having a hard time early on, purchasing powerups should make future runs a little bit easier.

For this game's asking price, it's dirt cheap for what it has to offer. There are tons of unlockable characters and extra stages to play beyond the 5 main stages. All achievements actually unlock extra content so they serve much more of a purpose than just intrinsic value. The only extra paid content is the soundtrack which is also worth a listen to and two DLC packs which add even more extra maps, characters and weapons, both of which are also dirt cheap and well worth the asking price.

151433188.review:
[b]Golden Egg[/b] is an item pickup that permanently increases a random stat on the player's current character by a small amount. It can be purchased repeatedly from the merchant or the eggman for 10,000 Gold. One is dropped from killing one of the four Masked Guardians or a Moon Guardian and five are dropped from killing the Reaper with Infinite Corridor or Crimson Shroud.

Each Golden Egg will provide a small permanent boost to 1 of the 19 stats available by the following amount:

+1 Max Health
+0.1 Recovery, Armor, Amount, Revival, Reroll
+1% Movement Speed, Might, Projectile Speed, Duration, Area, Luck, Growth, Greed, Curse
-0.5% Cooldown
+0.3 Magnet
+0.2 Skip, Banish
Golden Eggs boosts the character's starting stats. It does not however increase the character stats while in-game. As a result, any golden eggs obtained in-game will take effect for the next game session.

There is a hard cap on certain stats, where even if you get enough eggs to surpass that number, the game will only boost the stats by the listed amount:

900% might
400% projectile speed
400% duration
900% area
-90% cooldown
+10 amount

What kind of game is Vampire Survivors?

It's a passion project. It's a fan favorite. It's an unsent love letter to the glory days of vampire hunting. It's a wish list that only has "Copyright Infringement Lawsuit" scrawled on it in increasingly desperate script. It's a chaotic ballet of violence and chicken. It's an epic battle against the unending undying. It's a cartoonish depiction of one hero's struggle against one million foes. It's a game you administrate more than you play. It's a casual severity. It's a sleeper hit that came in the night like Double Santa teamed up with a Birthday Demon to slap you with a monkey's paw and make all your wishes come true. It's a silly, serious, bloody, magical, comical, whimsical, super cereal romp that never takes itself cereally.

What kind of game is Vampire Survivors?

It's easily one of my favorites.

It's not often you boot up a game for the first time and know almost immediately that this is THE GOOD STUFF.  VS is like that as you run around becoming a little pixellated ball of death, slaughtering the minions of darkness as they throw themselves at you. Then, the chest appears.  The music, the lights--it's a pure dopamine drip. 

Anyway, yeah, last Christmas Valve locked my steam account because I tried to process too many transactions when I went to send a copy to all my friends in too short a time. For about two weeks, I would log on and like 7-8 people playing Vampire Survivors on my FL at a time, and, considering we all have shameful game backlogs, that's really the best metric I have for how much fun VS is to play.

Now, of course, we've had two paid DLCs and regular free content updates as well, and it's been fun watching my friend list flip over to VS whenever there's new content available.  New levels, new engine, co-op....Poncle keeps giving back to the players and I am here for it.

There was a time when everyone was playing this game.
Most of them would tell you it was like crack, and they just couldn't put the game down.
While others high production costs games existed, somehow, this little game had hooked players worldwide, and they just couldn't put it down. I just looked at that phenomenon with some distance, not really caring about it. I had, at the time, others things to do.

I saw the game run, it seemed funny, and the amount of absurd power a character could attain amused me enough to check the store page. Game was cheap, so I told myself, why not, right?

Jumping in, it was a constant pleasure. First steps are a bit rough, but it takes about 10 hours pretty much go from "Oh god oh god I'm swarmed!" to being an absolute monster. And then it only becomes more crazy. The game is quite easy to break on your knee, but it doesn't means it is exactly easy to achieve, or mindless either. And it many way, it's a good thing, as this game is a big power fantasy where you go from one character throwing a few projectile to some kind of pixeled abomination throwing so many effects on the screen it's almost impossible to get a good grasp of what's happening, but you assume things are dying everywhere.

The game doesn't take itself seriously at all, everything is humorous, from the items, to what they do, to the monsters and their bestiary descriptions. The soundtrack is full of great pieces that keep your blood pumping as you go around murdering enemies with a kinder surprise powered up by a spinach.

To make things even better, the game receive new content, both free and paying DLCs, making coming back to it a pleasure just to discover new content... And absolutely brutalise it in few hours flat, because you're an absolute brute piloting a caterpillar powered by an addiction for Faberge eggs.

Make no mistake, if you wonder why this game has so many clones, it's because it is THE game that came out of nowhere, and was full of greatness the players almost universally loved. This is where it all began, and while it will be imitated, it will probably never be equalled. Many will try to jump on the bandwagon to try to get the Vampire Survivor money, but they will never be able to claim the merit to be original.

Cheap, with a lot of content and more added to it, funny, enjoyable and well designed. There is pretty much no reason to not play it.

151018615.review:
Recently 100%'d the achievements and secrets for Vampire Survivors, but there are so many more things to achieve yet in the game. Spent the entirety of this time playing it on Steam Deck both docked and undocked. 

I can't add too much to my review that hasn't already been said thousands of tines before. You go into the game thinking it's going to be low effort, low reward, low entertainment... but it hooks you with the reward cycle. You feel low powered, but then you get a power up or figure out how to tackle your previous time and keep going. Or you get major hits of serotonin when you collect a ton of XP gems or get an "epic" chest of 5 items. It's all really simple sounding, but it hooks you in until you can't stop.

One thing that really impresses upon me is the humorous descriptors and lore behind the game. I don't know how long it's going to take, but surely one day I'll find that vampire!

There are more updates coming to the game constantly, and the most recent one added a new map, enemies, weapons, a character, and relic. The update coming later on after I've hit review is supposed to be an "adventure" mode. Gives some more story, and a new way to play. I'm excited to get into that! So, please hurry up, poncle! (Affectionate)

150726922.review: This is an extremely fun, mostly brain dead, game that can keep you entertained for hours on end. It is extremely simple, you move about with your selected method of movement and the weapons auto fire on a set interval. As time goes by enemies spawn, and the more time passes during a run, the more enemies spawn and at higher "difficulty" levels (they mostly have more Health and higher Attack). There are certain combinations you can make with the weapons to created evolved versions of the weapon, with some being as simple as have a passive and the weapon at a certain level, while others require multiple previous evolutions of other weapons. The art style is very old school inspired as are the characters. I'd recommend this game to anyone that is looking for something simple to kill the time that is, at the same time, very fun.

This game has perhaps become a staple in reverse bullet hell games. It's got an outstanding nostalgic rendering style that very heavily cribs from Castlevania and its ilk, very accessible gameplay and mechanics, and it is pretty much very easy to run and run through - a game usually cannot play beyond 32 minutes unless if you go out of your way to turn on endless mode.

The music is solid, and gets (very simply) remixed within the game between game modes, the presentation is fresh, and few runs are unsalvageable.

I've happily gotten all the DLC, my partner happily got this game double on Steam and on the Nintendo Switch. The developer really has gone out of its way to make this their labour of love.

Vampire Survivors is an absolute gem in the world of indie games! This roguelike action game delivers an immersive experience that keeps you on the edge of your seat. The blend of strategy and fast-paced combat is incredibly addictive.

What truly sets Vampire Survivors apart is its innovative mechanics. The idea of playing as a vampire survivor striving to endure against endless waves of enemies is captivating. The skill tree system allows for diverse playstyles, making each run feel unique. The developers' dedication to regularly updating the game with new content and improvements speaks volumes about their commitment to the players.

The community around Vampire Survivors is fantastic, fostering discussions, strategies, and a shared passion for the game. Whether you're a seasoned gamer or new to the genre, this game offers an enjoyable experience that keeps you coming back for more. Kudos to the developers for creating such an engaging and thrilling game!

150394294.review:
TL;DR at the bottom

Vampire Survivors is a rising indie game it seems and from recommendation from my brother, I decided to pick it up.

Vampire Survivors is addicting, blind dumb fun, and simple to play. I mean, it was a mobile game first so I'd be surprised if it was complex. It also boasts a variety of gameplay choices, branching upgrades, loadouts, character stats, and more. Most of this you can kinda ignore if you want, but those who want to gun for something specific or want to build the best or funnest build they can think of will truly find it fun.

It's kind've a roguelike-light. It's a great game for those who want to try rogue-likes but find the branching paths, hidden bosses, difficulty, and more of games like Hades, Enter the Gungeon, and of course The Biding of Isaac too daunting or intimidating. This game is also a rarity in this day and age. Especially for a mobile game, where you buy the game and enjoy it. No ads, no in-game purchases, just play the game. There is DLC if you want more content and to support the creator(s) more like me, but they're totally not necessary.

The gameplay is addicting and while can get tiring during the longer runs when you're completely unstoppable since all the attacking is auto and really you just control your walking and the menus, it still can be fun to watch the pixels do the thing and your brain chemicals go brrr. When you want to just unwind and watch literal tens of thousands of monsters die easily, this is a fun pick up and play game.

It's not a 10/10 since I don't come back to it regularly and already 10 hours in has already kind've exhausted most of its replay value for me. But those 5-7 hours before it started getting boring? Some good stuff. And hey, it's only $5. In the age of games costing 14x that price and giving almost none of the fun, why not pick it up?

TL;DR Don't expect deep gameplay from Vampire Survivors. It's a good pickup and play game when you just want to see things die and feel powerful. Pay $5, get a dopamine vending machine with no price on the drinks.

9/10

150238416.review:
It is hard to fully understand in just which the scope of Vampire Survivors effect on gaming has been. What felt like overnight everyone was suddenly addicted to this game, and not long after games that take inspiration from this format were cropping up left and right. The simplicity of the game and the awesome feeling the game feels by playing it are the main two contributing factors to this success, which is why this is an easy recommend to someone looking for an addicting game to dig their claws into.

Instead of being able to attack enemies directly, your character will do automatic attacks with abilities and it's up to you to line some attacks up correctly while collecting gems from enemies in order to level up, unlocking new abilities and making current ones stronger. Each level is a half hour of gameplay but this absolutely flies by, as your builds can start to decimate enemies. Fully leveled up weapons can "evolve" in specific combinations making you reach godly levels by the end of just this 30 minute session. I've had fun doing all sorts of different builds to see which evolutions worked best together over time, and still just scratched the surface with all sorts of content and secrets this game is hiding.

The game has so many secrets, maps, and characters that promote different playstyles that approaching this from a casual viewpoint I had a lot of fun. The biggest selling point here is the price tag; it's just a few bucks to check this game out and sink an entire evening into without even realizing it.

150090137.review:
There's some gameplay experience spoilers coming down, but tldr: Game's pretty good, and is an absurd deal for $5 USD.

Every other reviewer says it better, but yes this game is highly addictive and really has "staked" a claim in its own genre at this point (even if Magic Survival was first).

I think visuals and weapon design go a long way here. There are lots of this "single stick bullet hell" games coming out now, but the visual design (inspired from a slot machine) makes it feel incredibly satisfying and very timesink-y. You will want to play over and over and over again, win or lose!

Unlike many other comments, I do have some really minor problems with the game, mostly that some characters and weapons are hilariously unbalanced and better than others. Not even talking about [spoiler] Queen Sigma [/spoiler] (who is kind of designed around that point), but even "midgame" characters like P[spoiler] ugnala [/spoiler], who have insane damage output both for the early and late game, and thus effectively will always have "better runs". Not really a "devs nerf this" thing, but it can be discouraging for those who want to focus primarily on one character if that character has to reset runs more frequently due to rougher starts.

I also think that, while it's their mostly as an easier way to [spoiler] kill the reaper at the end of the run and unlock Red Death, the Infinite Scaling weapons (Infinite Corridor and Crimson Shroud) just kind of nullify some of the fun challenge the game has normally. Perfectly fine thing to have, I would just encourage everyone to try challenges and not use it once to see how you can handle the reaper. [/spoiler]

Music is great, visuals are insanely fun to look at for my ADHD brain, and canonically trans witch character makes me very happy. I love VS, despite it's lack of challenge, and I will always appreciate it as a wonderful casual game to use for de-stressing after a long day.

149838406.review:
This is the game that started the craze, by reminding everyone that Crimsonland used to exist and being more fun than it looked. Now that there are a million imitators? It's still ok, but that's about it.

I can respect the devs; they started out making a game they felt like making, and when it became an enormous success they... kept making the game they felt like making. It's essentially unchanged from the first time it came out, just more characters who are minor variations on the same thing and more weapons that are... minor variations on the same thing. It's still a one-stick, no-button game. The sprites are animated now, kind of, but they're still quite basic.

The game is fun enough if you aren't looking for something stimulating; every run is similar and if you've powered up sufficiently in the unlocks then at around 10-15 minutes into each run you'll reach a point where you can more or less stop paying attention and read on your phone or whatever until the stage ends.

It's a great time-waster for the price, and not a single thing more than that. If you want anything else, get one of the many games that came after it that improve or elaborate on various aspects.

Vampire Survivors introduces a refreshing and captivating take on the roguelike genre, offering an addictive and challenging gameplay experience. The game stands out for its combination of action-packed combat, rogue-lite elements, and its distinctive vampire-themed setting.

One of the game's highlights is its fast-paced and strategic combat system. Players are tasked with battling through hordes of enemies as a vampire, utilizing a variety of abilities and weapons to survive each encounter. The fluidity and intensity of the battles create an exhilarating and immersive experience, keeping players on their toes throughout each run.

Vampire Survivors' roguelike elements, such as procedural generation and permadeath, add a layer of unpredictability and replayability. Every run feels fresh and different, offering new challenges and opportunities for players to experiment with various strategies and unlock new abilities and upgrades.

The game's pixel art style and visuals are not only aesthetically pleasing but also contribute to the game's overall charm. The retro-inspired graphics complement the gameplay, creating a nostalgic yet engaging atmosphere.

Moreover, the game fosters a sense of progression, allowing players to unlock new characters, abilities, and upgrades as they advance. This progression system incentivizes players to dive back in and continue honing their skills while exploring the various options available.

The developers' commitment to the game is evident through regular updates and community engagement, ensuring that the player base feels heard and involved in the game's evolution.

In summary, Vampire Survivors presents an addictive and entertaining rogue-lite experience with its dynamic combat, procedural generation, and retro aesthetics. Its challenging gameplay, progression system, and developer support make it an enjoyable choice for those seeking a thrilling and replayable action game within the roguelike genre.

A Fangtastic Roguelike Vampire Experience

Rating: ★★★★☆

Vampire Survivors is a captivating and unique roguelike experience that puts you in the fangs of a vampire as you navigate a challenging world of darkness. Here's a four-star review that captures the essence of the game:

"Vampire Survivors takes the classic roguelike formula and infuses it with a delightful dose of vampiric charm. Playing as a vampire attempting to survive against hordes of enemies, the game offers a challenging and engaging experience.

The core gameplay loop revolves around exploring procedurally generated levels, defeating enemies, collecting power-ups, and making difficult choices along the way. The game's roguelike elements, which include permadeath and randomly generated environments, ensure each run is unique and unpredictable.

One of the game's standout features is the variety of vampire abilities at your disposal. These powers range from transforming into a bat to mesmerizing enemies, each offering a different playstyle and strategy. Experimenting with these abilities is one of the most enjoyable aspects of the game.

The pixel art style is charming and fitting for the game's dark theme. The soundtrack complements the atmosphere, creating a sense of immersion.

However, it's important to note that Vampire Survivors can be challenging, and early runs may end quickly. Learning the mechanics and mastering the abilities takes time and practice.

In summary, Vampire Survivors is a unique and enjoyable roguelike experience that offers a fresh perspective on the genre. Its challenging gameplay and variety of vampire powers make it an engaging choice for fans of roguelikes and dark themes. With its procedural generation, it promises endless hours of fun and replayability, ensuring that every run is a new and exciting adventure in the world of darkness."

I generally don't like this genre of games. However after watching some YT vids I found it interesting. I am really too sleepy for a full review but see that 16 hours of game play? Yeah that has been in one sitting after purchase. It is fun and addicting.

So I am new to these types of games. I think the genre is called Horde Survival or Reverse Bullet Hell (which I definitely do not like). So you acquire weapons and spells and such and have to fend off Tens of thousands of monsters that get progressively more difficult. There are flashes and effects on the screen constantly so if you are sensitive to these things be warned.

Now one thing needs be mentioned. It is an AUTO-BATTLER. You need not worry about hotkeys for certain attacks etc. You are only need move around. Sounds boring right? Well it is not. It gives the feel of the old Arcade some of us used to spend hours in and rolls of quarters... 

Standard fare in a type of rouge-lite...bosses, chest, unlocks, further characters to unlock, buffs to purchase with in-game coin. NO MICRO TRANSACTIONS. (The bane of all modern day gaming, with POE being the exception)

It is just fun. Not too hard and is very fun to combine different spells and weapons and them to special status. Special status comes from combining, you know the drill.

3 days of owning the game now 32 hours play time and not NEARLY through with all the content.

IMO this game is really for everybody. Perhaps serious RPG players or competetive gamers will not like it much. But I think anyone would be pressed to say it is a bad game.

All that being said, this was my first game in the genre and have already bought Halls of Torment. Got my eye on a few others as well.

149474420.review:
Day 34 - Il Molise (South)

Once again we travelled at night. Something about keeping our movements hidden from the Reaper.
I cannot shake the feeling that something is off. That I am being mislead.
For famous Vampire hunters the Belpaese clan have not managed to show much in way of Vampire hunting. 
Their skill at arms is immeasurable, to be sure; they cut down swathes of enemies as if they were wheat before the sickle.
Yet so far, we have not managed to find a single Vampire and drive a stake through its heart.
Master Antonio keeps insisting that we are hot on his trail and he cannot flee forever, but I am starting to have my doubts.

The fight was tough today. The waves of thralls bore down on us with unrelenting persistence, but we managed to persevere.
After wading once through the endless waves we found another accursed coffin, once again however there was no Vampire inside.
Only a another hapless fool, "trapped" inside the casket. They thanked us, just like the others did. This one too seemed to recognise the Belpaese folks, yet they still acted as if they had just met.
Are they truly trapped? Are we actually hunting a Vampire? 
Or is this just a pretext to find and free the true occupants of those coffins and set them loose.

Lord preserve me. I think I am aiding the Vampires Survive, not Surviving the Vampires.

- Father Domario

149306463.review:
juegazo

receta de alfajores de maizena 

200 gramos harina
300 gramos Maizena
1/2 cucharadita bicarbonato de sodio
2 cucharadita(s) polvo de hornear
200 gramos manteca
150 gramos azúcar
3 yemas
1 cucharada esencia de vainilla
1 cucharadita ralladura de limón
dulce de leche
coco rallado

Tamizar la Maizena®, la harina, el bicarbonato y el polvo para hornear.

En un bowl, batir la manteca con azúcar. Agregar las yemas de a una, mezclando bien cada vez.

Al mismo bowl incorporar poco a poco los ingredientes secos ya tamizados (harina, Maizena®, bicarbonato y polvo para hornear). Incorporar la esencia de vainilla y la ralladura de limón y mezclar bien hasta formar una masa homogénea.

Estirar la masa (sin amasarla) hasta que quede de 1/2 cm de espesor sobre una mesa espolvoreada con harina. Cortar con moldes en forma circular.

Colocar en una placa limpia y cocinar en horno moderado durante 15 minutos. Una vez que las tapas estén cocidas dejarlas enfriar.

Formar los alfajores, uniéndolos de a dos tapas con abundante dulce de leche en el medio. Una vez hecho pasar la parte con dulce de leche por el coco rallado.

VS is deceptively simple. Very little instruction or ceremony, all you need is a finger/thumb. Pick a character, level, move your guy around to avoid getting hit. Congrats, you've already covered a significant portion of the game's mechanics. Simple enough to play on the toilet, during a work meeting, at a funeral, whatever. However, it has a delightful and satisfying progressive reveal, and said simplicity disguises a surprising amount of nuance and depth. Even the art and tone have a flippant nonchalance that is beguiling and weirdly sophisticated. It can get quite challenging, taunting you to step up or check out. It may look cheap and flimsy, but it has nearly as much polish as something like Hades yet is far more casual and accessible. It's also a crazy dopamine factory for collectible and achievement hunters. Works great on Steam Deck. Buy it.

149234244.review:
The relationship I have with this game is... complicated. Or maybe not, as it can be summarized with pure absolute spite. Like taking a bite out of a spicy meal that you hate the the feeling of, yet you keep eating it. The flavor is oddly soothing in the middle of the agonizing pain you feel throughout your body, but you keep eating it. You can't let it defeat you. You're better than that. You're the one who will survive, as no true vampire would ever admit defeat to a meal. Through pure spite and agony, you will emerge victorious... That's how this game feels.

Because admittedly, I don't truly like these "walk around to look cool" games or "Bullet Heavens" as they're often called. It's neat to be on the other side and be the one spitting bullets everywhere, but I feel like playing it is a bit pointless; all you're doing is walking around and watching stuff die around you. Occasionally clicking to pick a new power or a fancy hat, which is neat, but not very engaging. I hardly have to think about anything except walking and pain. Yet I kept coming back; it was just a thing to do a lot of the time.

So as you can expect, the gameplay itself is pretty simple. Characters have unique starting items, or weird effects, and you kill stuff to level up, getting a new item every level or upgrading an existing item to a pre-set max. The interesting part comes in having two, or more, items that compliment each other. Once a weapon is maxed and you have the affiliated attachment for it, you can find a box by punching a larger than usual monster, by walking around them of course, and then having a chance to get a super item from said box.

To keep with the food comparison, it's like ordering a steak and making sure to order the proper side-dish, most likely potato based, and in doing so the chef is impressed and upgrades your original steak to a steak that now shoots flavor right into your mouth. Like a machine gun. It's nice, far more effective, and you skip that slow eating phase. All thanks to ordering the proper potatoes.

Now the downside of this system is that you better have the menu either memorized or stapled to the back of your hand, because there's a large variety of combos you can order in this game and some are just obscure. Like you can't order just one bird to snack on, you need /two/ birds at max quality or they won't fuse together to create the Apostle Chicken with butter sprinkled on top, y'know? And if you want to fuse your guns together, you have to read the book on how to properly cook them and re-alive yourself in order to get the guns to fuse together into /four guns/ that shoot /lasers/ - And no, I'm not exaggerating. 

But I'm also getting away from the point of a review; the overall theme of the game is walking around, upgrading stuff, using unique items, and eventually exploring the land while shooting more stuff to find even more secret items. Most of which are listed on the front door of this game's secrets menu, but most I either had to look up, or stumbled upon myself. Some were neat, some were 'eh', and some unlocked ways to literally kill death itself. Which is neat the first time, but kind of a chore otherwise. At least you get cool golden eggs to add to your list of snacks.

Overall, I find this game to actually be kinda boring to me, yet I'm still saying "Yes, you should get this game." Why? Because I've gotten every achievement there is to get. I refused to give up on this spicy meal until it was totally finished. I worked to get every unlock, every achievement, I even maxed out every little bonus thing you could because why not? It was snack time; I was hungry for something to do, so I did something. And you know what these chef devs said to me? "Neat. You're clearly still hungry, so here's more."

They added more achievements. They added another layer to the meal that I wasn't ready for... and they've done this three times now. So why do I keep coming back? Spite. Pure, unapologetic spite. I won't be defeated... and I don't think any of you should either. So snag this game and eat it. Survive. If I could do it, you can do it too. I believe in you.
